prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Eddie Fender
Description: A student working part-time at the offices of Edgeworth and Co. Studying to be an attorney.
Character 1
Name: Samson Tangaroa
Description: My client, and a man said to be the greatest confectioner of his generation.
Character 2
Name: Artie Frost
Description: The murder victim. Found dead inside Samson Tangaroa's chocolate work.
Character 3
Name: Judy Bound
Description: Assistant to Samson Tangaroa. She's fond of the work of sculptor Paul Halique.
Character 4
Name: Tyrell Badd
Description: The detective assigned to this case. A man of few words.
Character 5
Name: Carmelo Gusto
Description: A candy-crafting confectioner who's taking part in the contest.
Character 6
Name: Delicia Scone
Description: A confectioner who will do whatever it takes to achieve her goals.
Character 7
Name: Manfred von Karma
Description: The prosecutor in charge of this case. It is said that he has never lost a trial in these past 25 years.
Character 8
Name: Laurice Deauxnim
Description: Pseudonym of Larry Butz, my friend since childhood. He fancies himself as something of an artist.
Character 9
Name: Dick Gumshoe
Description: Homicide detective from the local precinct who's always first on the scene at any murder investigation.
Character 10
Name: Kay Faraday
Description: A self-styled Great Thief and so-called "second Yatagarasu" who's always looking to bag the greatest treasure of all -- the truth.
Character 11
Name: Verity Gavèlle
Description: A district court judge and member of the Committee for Prosecutorial Excellence, who also acts as its mouthpiece.
Character 12
Name: Eustace Winner
Description: The greatest prosecutor ever to prosecute... according to himself, anyway. In actual fact, his relationship with logic is tenuous at best.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Attorney's Badge
Description: Proof of my profession. Polishing it every day has become just another part of my daily routine.
Evidence 1
Name: Seal
Description: A seal that was found near the body when it was discovered. What could the design signify?
Evidence 2
Name: Crime Scene Notes
Description: Notes about the crime scene. The police have taken custody of the body.
Evidence 3
Name: Mr. Tangaroa's Teapot
Description: A Paul Halique piece with Tangaroa's fingerprints on it.
Evidence 4
Name: Contest Rules
Description: A piece of paper listing the rules for the contest.
Evidence 5
Name: Frame Finger Marks
Description: Someone left finger marks on the chocolate frame, but didn't leave any prints.
Evidence 6
Name: Mansion Key
Description: The one and only key that unlocks every door in the mansion. Tangaroa was in possession of it the entire time.
Evidence 7
Name: Salt Lamp
Description: Salt lamp found in Scone's room. Stained with the victim's blood.
Evidence 8
Name: Fake Confections
Description: Ms. Scone's so-called creations were all fake plastic models, covered in a thick layer of whipped cream.
Evidence 9
Name: Luminous Cloth
Description: Special color-changing cloth belonging to Scone. She has lost a roll of it, along with the device that powers it.
Evidence 10
Name: Chocolates
Description: Tangaroa's favorite, handmade by Bound. Rather misshapened, and incredibly sweet.
Evidence 11
Name: Instant Camera
Description: Takes photos that develop instantly. A new film cartridge has twenty exposures, but there are only three remaining.
Evidence 12
Name: Mr. Frost's Room
Description: A photo of Frost's sculptures, taken by Judy Bound. Two photos, one from Bound and one from Detective Badd.
Evidence 13
Name: Ms. Scone's Statement
Description: Frost's sculptures in the finals were "scrumptious", except for the lyre, which was salty.
Evidence 14
Name: Semifinal Entries
Description: Frost's and Gusto's creations had different designs, but tasted the same.
Evidence 15
Name: Ultimate Cookbook
Description: A book containing formulas for creating a cure for taste disorders and other chemical and pharmaceutical items.
Evidence 16
Name: Victim's Blood
Description: Frost's blood was found in the fountain, but not at the scene of the crime.
Evidence 17
Name: Family Photo
Description: A photo of Frost, Gusto, and their sons. Gusto's son visited his father daily up through the semifinal.
Evidence 18
Name: Prosecutor's Badge
Description: Proof of my profession. However, I prefer to keep it in my pocket.
Evidence 19
Name: IS-7 Incident Case File
Description: Documents providing an overview of the IS-7 Incident. Documents received from Fender, including his comments in red.
Evidence 20
Name: Gallery Pamphlet
Description: A pamphlet received upon entry to the gallery.
Evidence 21
Name: Winter Wing Photo
Description: Statues matching those made by the victim eighteen years ago.
Evidence 22
Name: Pisces Statue Sketch
Description: A sketch by Larry depicting the Pisces statue exactly as he saw it.
Evidence 23
Name: Used Blowtorch
Description: There are signs it was used just before the police arrived. Possibly to heat something?
Evidence 24
Name: Luminous Cloth
Description: Cloth that glows when connected to a full-spectrum light-emitting device. Delicia Scone's property. One of these was lost eighteen years ago. Given to Bound by Scone. Lost eighteen years ago, only to be rediscovered floating in the fountain.
Evidence 25
Name: Poison Gas Ingredients
Description: The gas was produced when bright red Ubiquium and pure white Asphyxion were mixed together.
Evidence 26
Name: Ultimate Cookbook
Description: A book containing formulas for creating a cure for taste disorders and other chemical and pharmaceutical items.
Evidence 27
Name: Frame Finger Marks
Description: Finger marks left by someone in Tangaroa's room. No accompanying prints.
Evidence 28
Name: Salt Lamp
Description: A photograph of the murder weapon from the IS-7 Incident. It's a salt lamp stained with Frost's blood.
Evidence 29
Name: Family Photo
Description: A photo of Frost, Gusto, and their sons. Gusto's son visited his father daily up through the semifinal.
Evidence 30
Name: Teapot
Description: Designed by Paul Halique. One of Judy Bound's prize possessions.
Evidence 31
Name: Ceramic Fragment
Description: Found in a puddle of tea. The design looks familiar.
Evidence 32
Name: Lift Cart
Description: Used by Frost to transport ice eighteen years ago. The top of the platform is wet.
Evidence 33
Name: Larry's Sketches
Description: Sketches depicting exactly what Larry saw.
Evidence 34
Name: Gemini Case Analysis Results
Description: Results of the analysis conducted on the melted contents of the Gemini case. [info] Detected: Salt, Sugar, Blood

Sugar composition matches that of sugar found in the pale blue liquid in Artie Frost's room eighteen years ago.

Sugar detected in fountain water also seems to be a match.
Evidence 35
Name: Chocolates
Description: Handmade by Bound. Slightly melted after being kept in her pocket.
Evidence 36
Name: Statute of Limitations
Description: A book explaining the statutes of limitations of various crimes. [info] There are several conditions under which the time limit can be put on hold and extended:
If a suspect goes to a foreign country, then the time limit is put on hold until they return.
If any possible accomplices are put on trial, then the time limit is put on hold until the accomplice's verdict is reached.
If charges are pressed to demand compensation, then the time limit is put on hold until this procedure is cleared up.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: Gusto and Frost's relationship?
Person: von Karma
Testimony 1
Testimony: It's obvious the only relationship they had was that they happened to participate in the same contest.
Person: von Karma

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's tackle this problem. I need to find a pair of evidence and testimony that contradict each other. Let's start by reviewing the provided information step by step.

First, the characters listed don't seem directly relevant here since the question is about evidence and testimonies conflicting. The key is to look at each evidence and testimony to see if there's a discrepancy.

Looking at the testimonies, there's only two from von Karma. Testimony 0 is a question about Gusto and Frost's relationship, and Testimony 1 is von Karma's answer stating their only relationship was participating in the same contest.

Now, checking the evidences. Evidence 13 mentions that in the semifinals, Frost's and Gusto's creations tasted the same despite different designs. Evidence 14 is the Ultimate Cookbook with formulas, but maybe not directly related. Evidence 16 has a family photo showing Frost, Gusto, and their sons, with Gusto's son visiting up to the semifinal. That suggests a closer relationship beyond just being in the contest. Evidence 34 mentions analysis results showing sugar matches between Frost's room and the fountain, possibly linking past events. But the key point here is the family photo (Evidence 19 or 28 or 29? Wait, checking the evidence list again.

Wait, looking at the evidence list again, Evidence 17 is Family Photo: "A photo of Frost, Gusto, and their sons. Gusto's son visited his father daily up through the semifinal." Wait, actually in the given evidences:

Evidence 16: Family Photo: "A photo of Frost, Gusto, and their sons. Gusto's son visited his father daily up through the semifinal."

Evidence 28 is another Family Photo with the same description. Hmm, maybe duplicates, but the point is, there's evidence (Evidence 16 or 28) showing that Frost and Gusto had a family connection, possibly indicating a closer relationship than just being in the contest. 

Von Karma's testimony (Testimony 1) says their only relationship was participating in the contest. But the family photo evidence suggests they knew each other beyond that, maybe as friends or colleagues with shared family ties. Therefore, Evidence 16 (or 28) contradicts Testimony 1.

Wait, the exact evidence numbers need to be checked. Let me confirm:

Looking at the Evidence list:

Evidence 16: Family Photo: "A photo of Frost, Gusto, and their sons. Gusto's son visited his father daily up through the semifinal."

Evidence 28: Family Photo: "A photo of Frost, Gusto, and their sons. Gusto's son visited his father daily up through the semifinal."

So both 16 and 28 have the same description. Maybe a duplication, but the user might have intended one. Let me check the testimony again.

Testimony 1 by von Karma says their only relationship was being in the contest. But the family photo shows they were connected enough to be in a family photo together, implying a closer relationship. Therefore, Evidence 16 (or 28) contradicts Testimony 1.

Alternatively, maybe Evidence 13 (Semifinal Entries) which states their creations tasted the same, but that's about their contest entries. However, the family photo is more directly about their personal relationship.

So the conflicting pair would be Evidence 16 (or 28) and Testimony 1. Since the user might have numbered them as 16 and 28, but in the list, the first occurrence is Evidence 16. Therefore, the answer is {"evidence": 16, "testimony": 1}.
</think>

Person: von Karma
Testimony 2
Testimony: Until the day before the finals, they worked on their desserts together.
Person: von Karma
Testimony 3
Testimony: Why? Because Gusto had poor design sense, and Frost was a novice at baking.
Person: von Karma
Testimony 4
Testimony: Their cooperation lasted only through the semifinals. For the finals, they were on their own.
Person: von Karma

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's tackle this problem step by step. I need to find a pair of evidence and testimony that contradict each other. Let me start by reviewing all the provided information carefully.

First, the characters involved are listed, but I'll focus more on the evidences and testimonies. The key here is to look for any contradictions between what an evidence states and what a testimony claims.

Looking at the testimonies from von Karma (Character 7), specifically Testimony 3: "Their cooperation lasted only through the semifinals. For the finals, they were on their own." This suggests that Gusto and Frost stopped collaborating after the semifinals and worked independently in the finals.

Now, checking the evidences, Evidence 14 says: "Semifinal Entries: Frost's and Gusto's creations had different designs, but tasted the same." Wait, if their semifinal entries already had different designs but the same taste, that might indicate they were still collaborating in the semifinals. But von Karma's testimony says their cooperation lasted only through the semifinals, implying that up to the semifinals they worked together. However, the evidence mentions that even in the semifinals, their designs were different. Maybe the cooperation was before the semifinals?

Wait, Testimony 3 says they worked together until the day before the finals, meaning their semifinal entries were done together. But Evidence 14 says their semifinal entries had different designs. If they were collaborating, their designs should be similar? Or maybe the taste being the same is the key here. The testimony says they worked together up to the semifinals, so their semifinal entries would be a result of collaboration. But the evidence says their semifinal entries had different designs but same taste. That could be a contradiction because if they collaborated, their designs might not be different, but their taste could still be the same. Alternatively, maybe the testimony is about the finals, not the semifinals.

Wait, the testimony says their cooperation lasted only through the semifinals, so after that, they were on their own. The semifinal entries, therefore, were done together, so their designs should be similar? But the evidence says the semifinal entries had different designs. That's a contradiction because if they collaborated on the semifinals, their designs would likely be coordinated, not different. Hence, the testimony claims they collaborated through the semifinals, but the evidence shows their semifinal entries had different designs, implying they weren't collaborating then.

Alternatively, maybe the testimony refers to working together on the finals, but the evidence says they had different designs in the semifinals. Hmm, need to parse the testimony again.

Testimony 3: "Their cooperation lasted only through the semifinals. For the finals, they were on their own." So up to semifinals, they worked together. The semifinal entries would then be a joint effort, but the evidence says their semifinal entries had different designs. That's conflicting because if they collaborated, their designs might not be different. Therefore, Evidence 14 (semifinal entries had different designs) contradicts Testimony 3 (they collaborated through semifinals, implying similar designs).

Alternatively, maybe the taste being the same is the key. The testimony might be about taste, but the evidence mentions both design and taste. The testimony doesn't mention taste, so the contradiction is about the designs. Since the testimony says they worked together through the semifinals, their designs should be similar, but the evidence says they were different. So that's a contradiction between Evidence 14 and Testimony 3.

Alternatively, maybe the testimony is about the finals. Let me check Testimony 4: "Their cooperation lasted only through the semifinals. For the finals, they were on their own." So the semifinals were collaborative, but the finals were solo. The evidence says that in the semifinals, their designs were different but taste same. If they collaborated in the semifinals, their designs should not be different. Therefore, the evidence contradicts the testimony.

So the correct pair would be Evidence 14 and Testimony 3. Let me confirm the numbering. Evidence 14 is the Semifinal Entries, and Testimony 3 is von Karma's Testimony 3. The JSON would be {"evidence": 14, "testimony": 3}.
</think>

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: 18 years after Monsieur Master was arrested, I was finally able to buy back this mansion.
Person: Kate
Testimony 1
Testimony: Then, in order to maintain it, I decided to manage it as an art gallery.
Person: Kate
Testimony 2
Testimony: I collected Pierre Hoquet's works from all over the world.
Person: Kate
Testimony 3
Testimony: After all, it was my dream to open the Zodiac Art Gallery.
Person: Kate
Testimony 4
Testimony: I prepared replicas of the sculptures in the Winter Palace based on the photos I took.
Person: Kate

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let me try to work through this step by step. The user provided a bunch of characters, evidences, and testimonies, and they want to find a pair of evidence and testimony that contradict each other. I need to go through each evidence and testimony to see where there's a conflict.

First, I'll look at the testimonies given by "Kate" (probably a typo for Kay Faraday, since Character 10 is Kay Faraday). Her testimonies are:

Testimony 0: She bought back the mansion 18 years after Master was arrested.
Testimony 1: She managed it as an art gallery to maintain it.
Testimony 2: She collected Pierre Hoquet's works.
Testimony 3: Her dream was to open the Zodiac Art Gallery.
Testimony 4: She prepared replicas of Winter Palace sculptures based on photos.

Now, looking at the evidences, I need to find something that conflicts with these statements.

Evidence 21 is a Winter Wing Photo: "Statues matching those made by the victim eighteen years ago." The victim here is Artie Frost. If the Winter Wing has statues that Frost made 18 years ago, but Testimony 4 says Kate made replicas based on photos, there might be a conflict here. Wait, but Testimony 4 mentions the Winter Palace, not the Winter Wing. Maybe a typo? Or maybe the Winter Wing is part of the gallery?

Evidence 21 says the Winter Wing's statues match those made by Frost. If Frost was involved in creating those statues, then Kate's claim that she made replicas based on photos (assuming the original was by someone else) might conflict. But if the original statues were Frost's, then her replicas would be based on his work, which aligns. Hmm, not sure yet.

Looking at Evidence 20: Gallery Pamphlet received upon entry. Maybe it lists the gallery's history or artists. If the pamphlet says something different about the gallery's origins or the sculptures' origins, that could conflict.

Wait, Testimony 4 says she prepared replicas based on photos she took. If Evidence 21 shows the statues are exactly like Frost's, maybe Frost created them originally, so Kate's replicas are of his work, which might not contradict. Alternatively, if the original statues were by someone else (like Pierre Hoquet, as per Testimony 2), then there's a conflict.

Wait, Testimony 2 says she collected Pierre Hoquet's works. So if the Winter Wing's statues (Evidence 21) are actually Frost's, that would conflict with her saying she has Hoquet's works there. Because then the statues would be Frost's, not Hoquet's, which would contradict her claim of collecting Hoquet's works. 

Alternatively, maybe the Winter Wing statues are part of the Hoquet collection. But the evidence says they match those made by Frost. So if Kate claims they're Hoquet's, but the evidence shows they're Frost's, that's a contradiction.

Therefore, Evidence 21 (Winter Wing Photo showing Frost's statues) vs Testimony 2 (she collected Hoquet's works there). That's a contradiction. 

Alternatively, maybe Testimony 4 says she made replicas based on photos, but Evidence 21 shows the statues are original to Frost, so she didn't make replicas but used originals. But the evidence says "statues matching those made by the victim eighteen years ago," which might mean they are replicas or copies, so that aligns with her testimony. Hmm, maybe not.

Alternatively, looking at Evidence 24: Luminous Cloth. Not sure. Evidence 34 mentions Gemini case analysis, but that's about sugar. Maybe not.

Wait, Testimony 0 says she bought the mansion 18 years after Master's arrest. If the IS-7 Incident Case File (Evidence 19) mentions when Master was arrested, maybe the timing doesn't add up. But without specifics on the dates, hard to say.

Alternatively, Testimony 4 says she prepared replicas based on photos she took. Evidence 21's statues are from Frost. If those statues were supposed to be Hoquet's (from Testimony 2), but they're actually Frost's, that's a conflict. So Evidence 21 and Testimony 2 contradict. 

So the answer would be Evidence 21 and Testimony 2. Let me check the numbers again. Evidence 21 is Winter Wing Photo, Testimony 2 is "I collected Pierre Hoquet's works from all over the world." 

Yes, that seems like a contradiction because the evidence shows the statues are Frost's, not Hoquet's.
</think>

prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Eddie Fender
Description: A student working part-time at the offices of Edgeworth and Co. Studying to be an attorney.
Character 1
Name: Samson Tangaroa
Description: My client, and a man said to be the greatest confectioner of his generation.
Character 2
Name: Artie Frost
Description: The murder victim. Found dead inside Samson Tangaroa's chocolate work.
Character 3
Name: Judy Bound
Description: Assistant to Samson Tangaroa. She's fond of the work of sculptor Paul Halique.
Character 4
Name: Tyrell Badd
Description: The detective assigned to this case. A man of few words.
Character 5
Name: Carmelo Gusto
Description: A candy-crafting confectioner who's taking part in the contest.
Character 6
Name: Delicia Scone
Description: A confectioner who will do whatever it takes to achieve her goals.
Character 7
Name: Manfred von Karma
Description: The prosecutor in charge of this case. It is said that he has never lost a trial in these past 25 years.
Character 8
Name: Laurice Deauxnim
Description: Pseudonym of Larry Butz, my friend since childhood. He fancies himself as something of an artist.
Character 9
Name: Dick Gumshoe
Description: Homicide detective from the local precinct who's always first on the scene at any murder investigation.
Character 10
Name: Kay Faraday
Description: A self-styled Great Thief and so-called "second Yatagarasu" who's always looking to bag the greatest treasure of all -- the truth.
Character 11
Name: Verity Gavèlle
Description: A district court judge and member of the Committee for Prosecutorial Excellence, who also acts as its mouthpiece.
Character 12
Name: Eustace Winner
Description: The greatest prosecutor ever to prosecute... according to himself, anyway. In actual fact, his relationship with logic is tenuous at best.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Attorney's Badge
Description: Proof of my profession. Polishing it every day has become just another part of my daily routine.
Evidence 1
Name: Seal
Description: A seal that was found near the body when it was discovered. What could the design signify?
Evidence 2

Evidence 6

Description: The one and only key that unlocks every door in the mansion. Tangaroa was in possession of it the entire time.
Evidence 7

Description: Salt lamp found in Scone's room. Stained with the victim's blood.
Evidence 8
Name: Fake Confections

Evidence 11

Evidence 13

Evidence 14

Evidence 15

Evidence 17

Description: A photo of Frost, Gusto, and their sons. Gusto's son visited his father daily up through the semifinal.
Evidence 18
Name: Prosecutor's Badge
Description: Proof of my profession. However, I prefer to keep it in my pocket.
Evidence 19

Evidence 20

Evidence 21

Evidence 24

Evidence 25

Evidence 34

Description: Results of the analysis conducted on the melted contents of the Gemini case. [info] Detected: Salt, Sugar, Blood

Sugar composition matches that of sugar found in the pale blue liquid in Artie Frost's room eighteen years ago.

Sugar detected in fountain water also seems to be a match.
Evidence 35
Name: Chocolates
Description: Handmade by Bound. Slightly melted after being kept in her pocket.
Evidence 36
Name: Statute of Limitations
Description: A book explaining the statutes of limitations of various crimes. [info] There are several conditions under which the time limit can be put on hold and extended:
If a suspect goes to a foreign country, then the time limit is put on hold until they return.
If any possible accomplices are put on trial, then the time limit is put on hold until the accomplice's verdict is reached.
If charges are pressed to demand compensation, then the time limit is put on hold until this procedure is cleared up.

Testimony 4

Person: Gusto
Testimony 5

Person: Gusto

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's see. I need to find a pair of evidence and testimony that contradict each other. Let's start by going through the evidences and testimonies one by one to spot any inconsistencies.

First, looking at the testimonies from Gusto (Character 5):

Testimony 0: Gusto says he cooperated with Frost until the finals, handling flavor while Frost did design. But in Testimony 4, he mentions that aside from not cooperating with Frost in the finals, the finals weren't much different from the semifinals. Wait, but Evidence 14 says that in the semifinals, Frost's and Gusto's creations had different designs but tasted the same. If Gusto was handling flavor for Frost until the finals, then in the semifinals, their entries would have the same taste because Gusto was involved in both, which matches Evidence 14. But Testimony 4 says the finals weren't much different from semifinals except not cooperating. However, in the finals, Gusto made his own entry, so maybe the taste would differ. But according to Evidence 14, in the semifinals, their tastes were the same. If Gusto's finals entry was on his own, perhaps the taste would be different. But the testimony says the finals weren't much different, which might imply the taste was still the same? Hmm, maybe that's a contradiction. Wait, let me check again.

Wait, Testimony 4 says "the finals weren't much different from the semifinals" except not cooperating. If in the semifinals they collaborated (so same taste), and in the finals Gusto went solo, then the finals entries would have different tastes. But if the testimony claims they were similar except for the cooperation, that might conflict with Evidence 14 which says in semifinals they had same taste but different designs. Wait, Evidence 14 says in the semifinals, their designs were different but taste same. So if in the finals Gusto didn't cooperate, his taste would be different, so the finals entries would have different tastes, making them different from semifinals. But the testimony says the finals weren't much different, which might imply the taste was still the same. That could be a contradiction. 

Alternatively, maybe Testimony 4 is saying that except for not cooperating, other aspects like the process were similar. Not sure. Maybe I need to look for another pair.

Looking at Testimony 5: Gusto mentions Frost's son and his own attended the same school. Evidence 17 (Family Photo) says Gusto's son visited up through the semifinal. Not sure if that's a contradiction.

Evidence 14: Semifinal entries had different designs but same taste. If Gusto was collaborating with Frost until the finals (Testimony 0), then in semifinals they might have collaborated too, leading to same taste. Which matches Evidence 14. But Testimony 4 says that the finals weren't much different from semifinals except not cooperating. So if in semifinals they were cooperating (same taste), and in finals they weren't, the finals would have different tastes, making them different from semifinals. But the testimony says they were not much different, so that might be a contradiction between Evidence 14 and Testimony 4. 

Wait, Testimony 0 says they cooperated until the finals. So in semifinals, they were cooperating, so taste same. In finals, Gusto made his own, so taste different. Thus, the finals entries would differ in taste from semifinals. But Testimony 4 says the finals weren't much different from semifinals except for not cooperating. That suggests that other aspects (like taste) remained similar, which contradicts Evidence 14's implication that taste was same in semifinals because they collaborated, and finals would have different. Therefore, the testimony claims the finals weren't much different, but evidence suggests taste would be different, hence contradiction between Evidence 14 and Testimony 4.

Alternatively, maybe Testimony 4 is referring to the process, not the outcome. The problem is that the user requires only one pair, so maybe this is the intended contradiction. Let me check again:

Evidence 14: Semifinal entries (Frost and Gusto) had different designs but same taste. 

Testimony 0: Gusto says they cooperated until the finals (so including semifinals?), handling flavor and design separately. So in semifinals, Gusto handled flavor for Frost's entry, so Frost's entry would have Gusto's flavor, and Gusto's own entry would also have his flavor. Thus, both entries would have same taste (since Gusto did the flavor for both), but different designs. That matches Evidence 14. 

Then in the finals, Gusto didn't cooperate, so his entry's flavor is his own, and Frost's would be his own. So their flavors could differ. Therefore, the finals entries would have different flavors, making them different from semifinals. But Testimony 4 says "the finals weren't much different from the semifinals" except not cooperating. If "not much different" implies the taste was similar, that's a contradiction. But if "not much different" refers to other aspects, maybe not. The testimony might be saying the structure of the contest was similar, not the taste. But the user might consider this a contradiction.

Alternatively, maybe another evidence and testimony pair. Let's see:

Evidence 34 (Gemini Case Analysis) mentions sugar composition matching that from Frost's room 18 years ago and fountain. Testimonies from Gusto don't mention that, but maybe not conflicting.

Evidence 21 is Winter Wing Photo showing statues made by victim 18 years ago. Testimony 2 from Kate (Character 10?) says she prepared replicas based on photos. But maybe that's not conflicting.

Looking at Testimony 0 and Evidence 14: Testimony says they cooperated until finals, so in semifinals they did too, leading to same taste which Evidence 14 confirms. So that's consistent. 

The contradiction is between Testimony 4 and Evidence 14? Let me see:

Testimony 4: "the finals weren't much different from the semifinals except not cooperating". If the taste was same in semifinals because of cooperation, and in finals they didn't cooperate leading to different tastes, then the finals would be different in taste. But the testimony says they were not much different, implying that the taste remained the same. That's a contradiction. So Evidence 14 (semifinal same taste) and Testimony 4 (finals not much different, so same taste?) would conflict because if they stopped cooperating, the taste would differ, making finals different. 

Therefore, the pair would be Evidence 14 and Testimony 4.
